Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Barriers to Engineering as a Career Choice for Appalachian Youth

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project seeks to understand the relatively low participation of Appalachian youth in the engineering workforce and engineering careers. By interviewing practicing engineers and college students majoring in engineering, the investigators will develop an understanding of how motivational and self-efficacy factors as well as the regional culture influence career choices. An array of appropriate theoretical frameworks will be used to understand the needs and culture of this underserved and understudied demographic group that stretches over many states.

The broader significance and importance of this project will be to contribute to an understanding of why Appalachian youth are under-represented in the STEM workforce. The project will work with an array of partners in K-12 and university education as well as industry to ultimately create interventions that can impact workforce development and thus regional economies. This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goals of transforming the frontiers through preparation of an engineering workforce with new capabilities and expertise. Additionally NSF's goal of innovating for society is enabled by building the capacity of the nation's citizenry for addressing societal challenges through engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Students from Appalachia are underrepresented in higher education in general and specifically in engineering majors and careers.  Prior research on underserved populations indicates that motivation-related theories such as self-efficacy, expectancy-value, social cognitive career theory, and future possible selves may help explain the participation gap. However, no current single theory appears to adequately explain barriers that limit engineering as a career choice for Appalachian youth.  Through this project, we proposed to develop a framework that explains the factors that limit Appalachian students’ pursuit of engineering careers and to identify potential interventions designed to broaden participation among this demographic. To build this framework, we began by answering three key questions:

1. What factors influence the career choices of rural Appalachian students?

2. How do Appalachian students perceive and understand careers in engineering?

3. What barriers inhibit rural Appalachian students from pursuing careers in engineering?

To answer these questions, we drew on existing motivation, career choice and identity theories to develop an integrated theory describing the career choice process, and specifically barriers to engineering careers for people from this region. We used a three-phased mixed methods study that began with qualitative interviews, guided by existing frameworks while being open to additional factors suggested by studies of Appalachian culture. The second quantitative phase used the student-centered results to conduct a survey to better understand educational stakeholder, including counselors, teachers and administrators, views of engineering careers.  In the third and final phase, the results from the first two phases were integrated to develop a possible framework and make recommendations on potential interventions.  Throughout the project, feedback from the project’s partners (representatives of schools, colleges, and corporations in the rural Central and Cumberland Plateau regions of Appalachia) were critical to insure continual integration of research and practice.
